chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of Gilbert's syndrome
chapter.summary: Covers the treatment of Gilbert's syndrome, what advice to give people with Gilbert's syndrome, and what drugs should be used with caution.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with Gilbert's syndrome?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Reassure a person with Gilbert's syndrome that:
    • No treatment or regular monitoring is required.
    • It cannot progress or cause chronic liver disease.
    • Any episode of jaundice should be self-limiting and should resolve within a few days; is not a sign of serious illness; and is not infectious.
      • Advise the person to seek medical advice if any episode of jaundice is more severe or persistent than usual, as this may indicate an alternative diagnosis which may co-exist with Gilbert's syndrome.
  • Advise the person that jaundice may be precipitated by:
    • Dieting or fasting.
    • Surgery.
    • Dehydration.
    • Alcohol ingestion — advise the person to drink alcohol within recommended limits (See the CKS topic on Alcohol for more information).
    • Infectious illness.
    • Heavy physical exertion.
    • Lack of sleep — see the CKS topic on Insomnia for more information on management strategies.
  • Provide sources of information and support for the person and their family/carers, such as the British Liver Trust which provides an information leaflet on Gilbert's syndrome.
  • Be aware that certain drugs should be used with caution in a person with Gilbert's syndrome:
    • Gemfibrozil (a fibrate) — drugs which inhibit uridine diphosphate (UDP)-glucoronyl transferase, the enzyme responsible for conjugation, can cause variable hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice (for further information see CKS topic Lipid modification - CVD prevention).
    • Statins when combined with gemfibrozil — simvastatin, atorvastatin, and rosuvastatin are only partially metabolized by UDP-glucuronyl transferase, but if statins are combined with gemfibrozil, there is an increased risk of drug toxicity including myositis (for further information see CKS topic Lipid modification - CVD prevention).
  • Consider referral to a gastroenterologist or hepatologist, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, if:
    • Other causes of liver disease are suspected.
    • There is uncertainty about the diagnosis — rarely, genetic testing may be available in some specialist centres to confirm the diagnosis of Gilbert's syndrome (rarely necessary in clinical practice).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Providing reassurance and advice
  • The recommendations on providing reassurance and advice are based on expert opinion in a gastroenterology textbook [Watson and Gollan, 1989] and the Oxford textbook of medicine [Thompson, 2010], and in review articles [Claridge, 2011; Sticova and Jirsa, 2013; BMJ, 2015].
Caution with certain drugs
  • The recommendations on using caution when prescribing gemfibrozil and statins to people with Gilbert's syndrome is based on information in the manufacturers' Summary of Product Characteristics and expert opinion in review articles [Strassburg, 2008; Claridge, 2011; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015a; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015b; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015c; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015d].
Referral to a gastroenterologist or hepatologist
  • The recommendations on referral are based on expert opinion in review articles [Hirschfield and Alexander, 2006; Claridge, 2011] and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
